notes:
1. Static Friction

Static friction acts between surfaces that are not sliding relative to each other. It opposes the tendency of motion. The magnitude of static friction ($f_s$) adjusts to match the applied force up to a maximum limit.

2. Limiting Friction

The maximum possible static friction force is called limiting friction. It occurs when motion is impending (about to start).

$$ f_{s,max} = \mu_s N $$
  • $\mu_s$: Coefficient of static friction.
  • $N$: Normal force perpendicular to the contact surface.

Before this limit is reached, $f_s < \mu_s N$ and $f_s$ equals the component of the applied force parallel to the surface.

3. Angle of Friction

The angle of static friction, $\phi_s$, is the angle between the resultant contact force and the normal direction when motion is impending.

$$ \tan \phi_s = \mu_s $$

solvedExamples.question: A block of weight W rests on a horizontal plane. A horizontal force P is applied. If the block does not move, the friction force is:
solvedExamples.explanation: As long as the block is static and not at the point of slipping, the friction force exactly balances the applied horizontal force to maintain equilibrium ($f_s = P$). It is only at the point of impending motion that $f_s = \mu_s N$.

solvedExamples.question: What happens if the applied horizontal force exceeds $\mu_s N$?

options.text: The friction force increases to match the applied force.
The object begins to move, and kinetic friction takes over.

solvedExamples.explanation: Once the applied force exceeds the maximum static friction (limiting friction), the static bond breaks, the object starts to slide, and the resisting force drops to the kinetic friction value ($f_k = \mu_k N$).
